text: with the little spare time he has drew
Houston enjoys a good jamming session
with friends the 31 year old may never
quite make it as a chart-topping
musician but if tech entrepreneurs
really are today's rockstars then he's
already fast approaching the Hall of
Fame with Dropbox an online file-sharing
service which has now wrapped up 300
million users across the globe today is
his seventh birthday oh yeah thank you I
still have the little thing from the
Delaware Secretary of State saying hey
you have a real company now in that time
he's taken Dropbox from scratch to a ten
billion dollar valuation with Wall
Street expecting a public share offering
soon he told me he's always been an
ideas man at heart the whole path
started when I was little and and my
parents had a computer and they made all
these games on it and and I would play
these games and I was really curious
about how they worked and that's how I
started learning programming and-and-and
I always thought that when I grew up I
wanted to make computer games his first
serious attempt at putting those skills
into practice was an online exam
preparation tool it failed but
serendipitously provided drew with the
Eureka moment for Dropbox I was on a bus
from Boston New York and I want I had a
big list of things I wanted to get done
and so I opened on my laptop about to
get to work only to realize and they
fish around in my pockets and I forgot
my thumb drive and I mean all those
things I want to get done I wasn't gonna
get any of them done and what happened
was I opened up the editor and started
writing some code because I was like I
never want to have this problem again
and even if I just solve it for myself
that was great but then it was clear
that that Dropbox inand when I first
started working on was something that
that all of us need
getting funding initially or getting
noticed initially wasn't plain sailing
view so it was a challenge to raise our
first money because what happened was
are these investors we would talk to
them and they'd be like look there are a
hundred of these storage companies and
so like why does the world need another
one of these I would respond to the
investment look dude yes there are a lot
of these things out there but do you use
any of them and invariably they'd say
one no at this stage he'd bulge on a
co-founder Arash Ferdowsi a fellow
student from MIT it's an opportunity to
get someone who really complements you
and someone who can ride the ups and
downs with you the hardest part about
especially the early days is they're all
the business challenges they're all the
product challenges but it's just a very
grueling experience and one day you're
on top of the world and you know someone
that you get your first article written
about you the next day there's a huge
bug and the site is down and you're
tearing your hair out and and you have
this your whipsawing between euphoria
and terror every day and guess what
that's still true today
he now employs around 700 staff many
scooting busily around the San Francisco
HQ keeping them well-fed and motivated
with gourmet food drew says building a
great team has been key to his success
when you look behind the curtain isn't
this surprisingly little magic meaning
all these companies were built to us by
getting us set like groups of smart
people together and just to try to make
the best decisions they can and just and
just solving one problem at a time and
just do that over and over and over
again and then sort of like compound
interest where if you make a little bit
better decisions a little bit better
people look a little bit harder you know
a day later a year later might not see
how much of a difference but like seven
years later then kind of a huge
difference and so but one thing I do
that's therapeutic as I read these
profiles of all these other companies
and what you the first thing you realize
is like oh my god these places were such
a mess and they still did okay
